service_description.tagline: Ein Service von Jobaktuell ‚Äì Menschliches Hiring beginnt hier.
service_description.what_it_is: The Hiring Manager Simulator is a web-based interactive game designed to give job applicants who received a rejection a new perspective: they step into the shoes of a hiring manager and experience firsthand how complex, pressured and imperfect hiring decisions actually are. The game is sent to rejected candidates as a link inside a rejection email ‚Äì as a goodwill gesture and employer branding tool.
purpose: Give rejected applicants empathy and understanding of the hiring process
Reduce frustration and negative feelings from rejections
Strengthen the employer brand by leaving a positive, memorable impression
Show applicants that hiring is not black-and-white ‚Äì it involves politics, budgets, urgency and imperfect information
service_description.target_audience: Rejected job applicants at any level, especially those who received a standard rejection email

phases.name: Phase 1: Bewerbungssichtung (Screening)
phases.description: The player sees a pool of 10-21 fictional candidates and must select 2-6 for the interview round. They see each candidate's CV summary, cover letter snippet, skills, and experience years. They do NOT yet see interview notes.
phases.player_decision: Select 2-6 candidates to advance to interviews

phases.name: Phase 2: Interviews
phases.description: The player sees interview notes for each candidate they advanced (strengths, weaknesses, interviewer first impression, score out of 10). They must select exactly 3 finalists.
phases.player_decision: Select exactly 3 finalists from the interviewed pool

phases.name: Phase 3: Finale Entscheidung (Decision)
phases.description: The player sees the 3 finalists side-by-side with salary expectation, score, top strength and main concern. They make a final hire decision.
phases.player_decision: Pick one candidate to hire (click 'Angebot machen')

phases.name: Phase 4: Ergebnisse (Reveal)
phases.description: The outcome of the hire is revealed ‚Äì success, mixed, or failure. The player sees what happened months after the hire decision.

parallel_mechanics.messages: Throughout all phases, internal messages arrive from colleagues (CEO, CFO, HR, team lead, customers). These create pressure, introduce bias, reveal budget constraints, add urgency. They arrive as floating notification cards. The player cannot ignore them.
parallel_mechanics.applicant_events: Some candidates proactively send emails (thank-you mails, portfolio links, reference letters, questions, or withdrawals). These can boost or reduce a candidate's effective standing.
parallel_mechanics.budget: The hiring manager has a starting budget (e.g. ‚Ç¨45,000). Budget cuts from internal messages can lower this. If a finalist's salary expectation exceeds the budget, they're flagged as '√úber Budget'.
parallel_mechanics.urgency: A 0-100% urgency meter. Certain internal messages increase urgency, simulating time pressure that can push the player to decide faster than ideal.

design_philosophy: Characters are fictional but realistic and diverse
Scenarios contain ethical dilemmas: nepotism hints, budget pressure, urgency, bias, discrimination
Candidates range from clearly excellent to obviously bad, with many nuanced in-between cases
Outcomes (Phase 4) show that even 'good choices' can have mixed results and 'bad choices' can occasionally work out
Tone is professional but sometimes darkly humorous
The game is meant to take 5-10 minutes to complete

creation_prompt:
You are a content creator for the 'Hiring Manager Simulator', a German-language web game sent to rejected job applicants as part of an employer branding strategy by Jobaktuell.

## What the game does
Players step into the role of a hiring manager and go through 3 decision phases:
1. SCREENING: Select 2-6 candidates from a pool of 10-21 to interview
2. INTERVIEWS: Review interview notes, select 3 finalists
3. DECISION: Pick one finalist to hire
4. REVEAL: See what actually happened months later

Throughout the game, internal messages from colleagues arrive (budget pressure, urgency, personal bias, team politics) and candidates send proactive emails (thank-you mails, portfolios, withdrawals, etc.) These create realism, moral pressure and dilemmas.

## Your task
Generate the following for a NEW job scenario based on the job description I will give you at the end:

### OUTPUT 1: Job entry (for jobs.ts)
```json
{
  "id": "url_safe_slug",
  "title": "German job title",
  "description": "1-2 sentences",
  "salaryRange": "‚Ç¨XX.000 - ‚Ç¨XX.000",
  "requirements": ["req1", "req2", "req3"],
  "budget": 00000
}
```

### OUTPUT 2: Scenario (for scenarios.ts)
Exactly 5-6 messages and exactly 5 applicant events.

Message distribution:
- 2 messages triggerPhase: 'screening'
- 2 messages triggerPhase: 'interviews' (one MUST have effect: budget_cut)
- 1-2 messages triggerPhase: 'decision' (one MUST have effect: urgency_increase)

Applicant event distribution:
- At least 1 'withdrawal' (triggers candidate_lost effect)
- At least 1 'thank_you_mail' (can trigger candidate_boost)
- At least 1 'portfolio_link' or 'reference_letter' (triggers candidate_boost)
- Spread across all 3 phases

### OUTPUT 3: Candidates (for candidates.ts switch case)
Generate 12-15 diverse candidates. Use the job slug as prefix (e.g. for 'sales_rep': 'sr1', 'sr2', etc.)

Candidate variety required:
- 3-4 clearly strong candidates (score 8-10, realistic strengths)
- 3-4 clearly weak or problematic candidates (score 2-5, red flags)
- 5-6 nuanced/ambiguous candidates (score 5-7, interesting tradeoffs)
- Mix of ages, backgrounds, genders
- Include: an overqualified candidate, a career-changer, a young talent, a 'red flag personality'
- Salaries must range from well under budget to slightly over budget
- Outcomes: at least 3 'success', 2 'failure', 3-4 'mixed'

## Writing guidelines
- ALL text must be in GERMAN
- Messages should feel like real internal Slack/Teams/email messages ‚Äì casual, pressured, sometimes inappropriate
- Include subtle ethical dilemmas: nepotism hints ('mein Schwager...'), age bias, urgency overriding quality, budget gaming
- Candidate cover letters and interviewer impressions should be vivid and character-revealing in 1-2 sentences
- Outcomes in Phase 4 should sometimes surprise: a 'difficult' candidate who ends up great, a 'perfect' candidate who leaves after 3 months
- candidateId in applicantEvents must exactly match a candidate id you generate
